One of the most promising strategies for removing excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is CO2 utilization. Here, we describe the effective synthesis of propylene carbonate utilizing CeO2–La2O3 (Ce–La) mixed oxide, combining propylene oxide with carbon dioxide. The addition of La2O3 (La) to CeO2(Ce) resulted in an increase in oxygen vacancy, reducibility, and support–support interaction. Modifying the La:Ce ratio leads to a fine–tuning of the reducibility of the oxide, which can be explained by the formation of oxygen vacancies in the ceria lattice upon La addition. This modification also permits tailoring of the oxide morphology (lattice parameter, pore structure, particle size, and surface area). Powder X–ray diffraction (P–XRD), temperature programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2–TPR), Raman spectroscopy, BET surface area, and X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used to analyze the physico–chemical properties of the developed materials. Additionally, it demonstrates excellent catalytic activity for the solvent–free cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide, yielding 86%, and it maintains its high stability over five cycles without changing its shape. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 utilization Cycloaddition Propylene carbonate Propylene oxide Metal oxides Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Climate change and global warming caused by greenhouse gases (GHGs) are among the biggest problems of the contemporary era. Climate change and global warming are widely believed to be largely caused by the greenhouse gas CO2 [1,2]. The enormous levels of CO2 produced by numerous sectors worsen global warming and are mostly to blame for droughts, flooding, and the extinction of plants and animals. About 77% of greenhouse gas emissions, or 35 billion metric tons, are attributed to CO2 [2]. Both the environment and human health are significantly impacted by these pollutants. Scientists are investigating methods to store or eventually use this molecule because they are concerned about the impact that emissions of carbon dioxide from burning fuel and other human activities have on the environment [3–5]. Consequently, there has been a greater push in recent years to use carbon capture and storage (CCS) and carbon capture and utilization (CCU) techniques to lower the atmospheric concentration of CO2. Because of its high implementation costs and absence of a long–term policy framework, CCS is technically challenging. Therefore, a better strategy to reduce CO2 emissions is to convert CO2 into useful compounds. Recently, there has been a lot of interest in direct chemical fixation of CO2 due to its non–hazardous carbon source [6,7]. Since CO2 is cheap, renewable, and has the potential to replace harmful C1 building blocks like phosgene, it is a desired C1 feedstock for the synthesis of several high–value compounds, such as urea, methanol, formic acid, and organic and inorganic carbonates and other molecules [8–11]. Due to its high atom efficiency, increased economic value, thermodynamic preference, and environmental benefits, the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides has garnered increased interest in recent decades [5,12,13]. Propylene carbonate (PC), one of the numerous five–membered cyclic carbonates, is used extensively in the chemical, cosmetic, pharmaceutical, paint, and plastics industries [14–16]. Additionally, it plays a crucial role as a reactive intermediate in the synthesis of important substances including dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and poly (propylene carbonate). Furthermore, it is utilized as an electrolyte in the production of modern lithium–ion batteries [17–19]. On the other hand, the reaction between epoxides and carbon dioxide can only take place in the presence of a catalyst and can be manipulated to produce a polycarbonate or a cyclic carbonate [20]. Several ionic liquids [21–24], quaternary ammonium salt/phosphonium salts [25,26], and metal–organic complexes [27–29] have been reported to work as catalysts in the cycloaddition of epoxides and carbon dioxide, out of the numerous catalysts produced for the process to date. The catalysts listed above, however, are all homogeneous. As a result, it takes time and is expensive to separate from the reaction mass. Thus, we concentrated mostly on reusable heterogeneous catalyst, which has advantages such as good conversion at moderate pressure and temperature as well as ease of separation and reusability. Many studies have been conducted on the structural characteristics and activity of catalysts in the interaction between propylene oxide and CO2 [30,31]. In general, the literature indicates that mixed oxides exhibit higher activity compared to mono oxides and outperform other heterogeneous catalyst types in terms of ease of manufacture, low cost, high thermal stability, and high activity [32]. Actually, the acidity and basicity of mixed oxide catalysts aid in the activation of CO2 and epoxide molecules, respectively. To obtain a high yield for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides, it is also crucial to select the appropriate mixture of metal oxides [33,34]. Due to the easy conversion of Ce4+ into Ce3+, cerium oxide plays a significant active role in redox processes as a material for oxygen storage and transfer. It has been demonstrated that doping ceria can enhance this performance even more because of its greater reducibility and oxygen storage capacity. Recent findings show that compared to other trivalent dopants including Sc, Mn, Y, and Gd, La dopings are even more effective at promoting the Ce4+/Ce3+ reduction process [35]. La2O3 oxide demonstrates a significant capacity for CO₂ adsorption, allowing for efficient capture and retention of carbon dioxide molecules. It generates stable lanthanum carbonate compounds at moderate temperatures, facilitating efficient CO₂ absorption. Significantly, the process exhibits reversibility at elevated temperatures, facilitating the release of CO₂ and the regeneration of La2O3 [36]. Several solid catalysts, such as CeO2, La2O3, and cerium–lanthanum mixed oxides (Ce–La), have been studied and characterized in this work in order to synthesize propylene carbonate without using a solvent [37]. Moreover, several factors have been carefully investigated to determine the catalyst with the best performance, including catalyst types, catalytic loading, CO2 pressure, temperature, and reaction interval. Stability tests have been carried out to determine the stability of the optimized catalyst for the synthesis of propylene carbonate. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate, Lanthanum Nitrate Hexahydrate, Ammonium hydroxide, Deionized water, Propylene oxide, Carbon dioxide, Propylene carbonate were purchased from sigma Aldrich in India. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Through co–precipitation, La2O3–CeO2 mixed oxide catalysts were developed. Following a modified procedure, a batch of 0.5 g was made. 100 mL of distilled water were used to dissolve 6.31 g of Ce (NO3)3.6H2O and 3.35 g of La (NO3)3.6H2O. A 5% NH4OH solution was then used to precipitate the mixture at a pH of around 9–10 at room temperature. Following a 24–hour aging period, the precipitate was filtered using deionized water and continuously rinsed until the filtrates pH reached a neutral level. The resultant solid material was calcined at 500°C for 4 hours with a ramping rate of 5°C/min in ambient air, after being dried for 12 hours at 100°C in an oven. 2.3 Catalyst characterization An Ultima IV X–ray powder diffractometer, made by the Japanese company Rigaku Corporation, was used to acquire the X–ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts. Ni–filtered Cu Ka radiation with a wavelength of 1.5406 A° was employed, and the scanning step size was set at 0.02°. The scan range was 10° to 80°, and the scan speed was 4° per minute. The 40 kV X–ray tube voltage and 20 mA current were used for the XRD experiments. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT–IR) spectroscopy was used to examine the catalysts. A Spectrum GX spectrometer made by Perkin Elmer in the USA was used to record the spectra. For the analysis, the scan range was chosen between 4000 and 350 cm–1. A Raman spectroscopy equipment, namely the Horiba Jobin–Yvon Lab Ram HR spectrometer, was used to acquire the Raman spectra of the catalysts. The 17–mW internal He/Ne laser in the spectrometer operated at 633 nm as the excitation wavelength. Data was gathered by examining different sites within the spectral range of 200–1200 cm−1, after the particle catalyst was uniformly distributed onto a glass slide. A thorough analysis of the morphological structure of CeO2 particles was conducted using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) at 200 kV utilizing a TECHNAI G2 USA model. To disperse the powder that had been combined with ethanol and exposed to radiation in an ultrasonic bath, a copper grid covered in a coating of carbon and formava was utilized. A Thermo Kα X–ray photoelectron spectrometer was used to analyze the catalysts via X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The energy of the monochromated Al Kα X–ray radiation employed as the excitation source was 1486.7 eV. At room temperature, the measurements were carried out. The carbon (C 1 s) peak at 284.6 eV was used as a reference to calibrate the spectra and modify the binding energies that were obtained. By subjecting the catalyst sample to temperature–programmed CO2 desorption using an Autochem 2010 device (made by Micromeritics Instruments, USA), the fundamental characteristics of the samples were ascertained. A 0.1–gram specimen was placed within a quartz tube and activated by drying it under a 20 mL/min helium flow, then adsorbing CO2 gas for 30 minutes at 373 K. The temperature range in which CO2 desorption takes place is 100°C to 600°C, and the heating rate is 10 K per minute. On a N2 adsorption equipment operating at 77 K, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured (Quadrasorb–SI V 5.06, M/s. The US company Quantachrome Instruments Corporation. Before the measurement, the samples were out–gassed for three hours at 573 K. 2.4 Methodology for the cycloaddition of PO and CO2 The PO and CO2 cycloddition reaction was conducted in a high pressure reactor that was mechanically agitated [28]. A thermocouple and a pressure gauge were installed in the reactor to track its internal temperature and pressure at all times. An aluminum cylindrical heater linked to the controller unit fed the reactor with heat. Liquid CO2 can enter the reactor at a desired rate owing to an SCF pump that connects the gas inlet valve at the top of the reactor to a liquid CO2 cylinder. The reactor was charged with a certain quantity of catalyst and the limiting reactant, PO, for each experiment. After heating the reactor to the appropriate temperature, the mechanical stirrer was started. An SCF pump was used to feed a predetermined volume of liquid CO2 into the high pressure reactor once the required temperature was reached. The reaction mixture was allowed to settle for a sufficient period after the liquid CO2 was charged into the reactor, or what is known as zero time, or t = 0. After the experiment was over, the reactor heating and churning were turned off, it was cooled in an ice bath, and any leftover CO2 was evacuated out. After filtering the reaction mixture, the catalyst was isolated, cleaned with acetone, and allowed to dry in a vacuum oven. The sample was taken out of the reaction mixture that had been filtered and analyzed through a Shimadzu GC–2014 gas chromatograph (GC). In order to optimize the reaction conditions, a number of parameters were examined, including catalyst types, CO2 pressure, catalyst loading, reaction time and reaction temperature. Studies on the reusability of catalysts were also carried out to evaluate the stability of the catalyst. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 The XRD pattern of (a) Ce and (b) 50Ce–50La shows the peaks associated with the CeO2 crystals (JCPDS: 004–0593) [38]. No additional La peaks were found in the pattern, indicating that La was perfectly incorporated into the Ce lattice. Both the Ce and 50Ce–50La materials crystallize into a cubic system with an Fm–3 m space group [39,40]. The peaks in the XRD pattern of the 50Ce–50La sample are broader when compared to pure Ce and other La loaded samples. The full width at half maximum of the diffraction peaks also increases in the composite, which can be attributed to a reduction in sample grain size. Also, the effect of La loading on Ce network has been confirmed with P–XRD analysis. One can notice in Fig. S1 that while increasing the loading of La, the Ce P–XRD peak position moves towards the lower 2θ position. The grain size was calculated using the Scherrer equation and found to be 10.1 nm, 9.2 nm, 7.9 nm and 8.4 nm for pure Ce, 25La–75Ce, 50La–50Ce and 75La–25Ce samples respectively. Interestingly, among all samples the lowest crystalline size was observed for 50La–50Ce samples. Due to the fact that the La3+ ion radius (0.106 nm) is larger than the Ce4+ ion radius (0.097 nm) when La is incorporated into Ce, La3+ ions replace Ce4+ ions in the crystal structure, which leads to the expansion of the crystal lattice. Rietveld refinement results of the XRD pattern clearly show that the lattice parameter and volume of the pure Ce are 5.4116 Å and 158.484 m3 respectively. Adding La with Ce increases the lattice parameter value to 5.4970 Å and volume to 166.109, respectively [40], indicating the expansion of the unit cell. The profile fitting of the samples is shown in the following figure. To determine the formation of Ce, La, and 50Ce–50La samples, FT–IR analysis was performed. The FT–IR spectra for the single and mixed metal oxides synthesized by the co-precipitation process and calcined at 600°C/5 h are shown in Fig. 2 a. They range between 1000 and 400 cm−1. All catalysts exhibited a metal–oxygen bond between 700 and 400 cm−1. The transverse mode of the cubic fluorite structure in the Ce sample is represented by a sharp, intense peak at 508 cm−1, whereas the longitudinal mode of Ce–O stretching is represented by a weak, intense peak at 436 cm−1 [28]. For the La sample, La–O stretching vibrations are linked to the broadband seen at 647 cm−1, whereas La–O bending vibrations are responsible for the short band at 517 cm−1 [29]. Therefore, the existence of La phases in the nanoparticle samples is confirmed by the presence of these La–O stretching and bending vibration bands [41]. It is interesting to note that the mixed metal oxide (50Ce–50La) sample only relates to the Ce pattern; the lack of the La pattern suggests that the particles are fully embedded in the Ce matrix. Furthermore, a significant change in the Ce stretching frequency to the lower wave number area suggested that the insertion of La had weakened the Ce–O bond. An effective method for obtaining information on the oxygen vacancies in oxide materials, particularly in solid matrices containing cerium, is Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 2b displays the Raman spectroscopy results for the Ce, La, and 50Ce–50La samples. One F2 g band, typically centered at ∼465 cm–1, is seen in the Raman analysis of pure ceria. This band can be seen as the symmetric breathing mode of the oxygen ions encircled by the cations [42]. This band shows that La3þ–doped ceria exhibits a global cubic fluorite-type structure and is susceptible to any disorder in the oxygen sublattice. Even though the 50Ce–50La Raman spectra looked like pure ceria, a few characteristics stand out. When doped with La3þ, ceria exhibits an asymmetric F2 g mode slightly displaced to a lower wavenumber and an enhanced FWHM compared to pure ceria. The combined effects of lattice expansion, decrease in crystallite size, the existence of oxygen vacancies, and reduction in Metal (M): Oxygen (O) vibrations upon introduction of La3p into the ceria lattice (deformation occurs in the crystal structure due to larger ionic radius of La3þ compared to Ce4þ) result in this shift. The integration of La3þ and the generation of 50Ce–50La are indicated by the F2 g band shifting and the absence of the peak corresponding to La, which is typically observed at 405 cm–1 and is related to the torsional skeleton mode of hexagonal units [42]. Furthermore, the XPS method was used to examine the oxygen species and surface metal oxide of Ce, La, and 50Ce–50La catalysts. In Fig. 3 , the chemical compositions and characteristics of Ce3d, La3d, and O 1 s were described. The coexistence of Ce3+ with two peaks at 900.5 and 882 eV and Ce4+ with two peaks at 897.8 and 916 eV was demonstrated by the Ce3d spectra in Fig. 3(a). The composition of the various surface Ce species (Ce3+ and Ce4+) was then ascertained by deconvoluting the spectra; it was found that Ce3+ was strongly correlated with the amount of surface electrophilic oxygen species [43]. The concentration of Ce species was calculated using the peak assignment approach from earlier research, and the deconvolution findings were displayed in Table 1 [44]. The findings demonstrated that the surface Ce3+ concentration of Ce/La in the present study was 52%, a substantial increase above the Ce3+ concentration of pure Ce (43%). It is evident that when La is inserted into Ce, Ce4+ can be reduced to Ce3+ with more efficiency. The insertion of La into the Ce network during the production of 50Ce–50La must be the reason for the significant shift in the XPS peak place of Ce3d for the 50Ce–50La sample towards the lower binding energy area, as further evidenced by Fig. 3a. Direct comparisons between the two catalysts would be challenging because pure La lacks Ce. La3d5/2 profiles were allocated to two of the primary peaks in Fig. 3(b), which were positioned at about 838 and 835 eV. La3d3/2 profiles were assigned to the other two peaks, which were placed at around 856 and 853 eV [44]. The peak location for Ce/La against La catalysts shifted slightly when comparing the binding energies for La3d5/2, indicating that Ce insertion altered the electronic characteristics of ceria and that there was a decrease in binding energy with La addition. Fig. 3c displays the resolved O 1 s core level spectra of the 50Ce–50La sample and pure Ce and La. The curve fit into three components for the pure ceria sample: the surface oxygen vacancy peak at 531.5 eV, the surface water adsorbed peak at 533.5 eV, and the low binding energy (∼530.17 eV) corresponding to lattice oxygen. According to the properties of the dopant ions, the oxide ion's charge is greatly impacted by the chemical environment around them, causing the peak to shift to either side. One can see in O1s XPS scan of 50Ce–50La sample the O lattice peak is greatly shifted towards the lower region. The shift suggests that ceria and La3p are mixed to form a Ce–O–La type connection [36]. The electron density may be pushed toward the oxide ion by the fundamental character of La3þ, resulting in a noticeable chemical shift of 0.82 eV. This would lead to weakly attached oxygen and a decrease in the Ce–O electrostatic attraction. The presence of oxygen vacancies in the samples is responsible for the high binding energy reported at around 531.5 eV. When comparing the 50Ce–50La sample to pure ceria, the peak intensity is higher, indicating that 50Ce–50La has more oxygen vacancies and is in a more reduced form [36]. Table 1 presents the observed Ov and Ce3+ percentages from the XPS analysis used to calculate the surface atomic molar ratio. HR-TEM examinations were conducted to observe the morphological and structural modifications and development process to confirm the particle size and shape of the 50Ce–50La and to confirm the results obtained from XRD, FT–IR, and Raman measurements. Moreover, the elemental composition of 50Ce–50La was systematically examined by HR-TEM–EDS mapping in order to better understand its composition. This process was recorded using EDS analysis, and the results are displayed in Fig. 4(a–d). The pictures clearly show that the 50Ce–50La nanomaterials contain Ce, La, and O components. Furthermore, the particle has a spherical shape, as seen by HR-TEM images (Fig. 4 e–j). The HR-TEM images showed that the average particle size of the 50Ce–50La is 4 nm, and the particles are formed in a uniform size. The catalyst particle size is controlled by a slower growth process and rapid nucleation, which could explain the small particle size and narrow size distribution. A deeper look at the particle ensemble and the orientation of the crystallographic planes are displayed in the micrographs in Fig. 5(a–e). The HR-TEM images show that some crystal plane regions overlap and that there are some minor steps. Mixed fringes of 0.164 nm, 0.274 nm, and 0.313 nm demonstrate the importance of these overlapping regions and the stages in the mixed oxide particles from a catalysis perspective. Fig. 5 b demonstrates the presence of several diffraction rings and the high crystalline nature of the ordered 50Ce–50La samples. The diffraction rings of the (111), (200), (220), (311), (400), and (331) planes of α phase of Ce–La are clearly apparent, and they correlate well with the XRD data (Fig. 3) [45]. The fundamental active sites on the catalyst surface are studied using the CO2–TPD characterisation technique. In Fig. 6(a), the CO2–TPD curve for the Ce, La and 50Ce–50La catalysts is presented. There are three distinct active sites for CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, which correspond to the three adsorption centers with stronger basicity, moderate basicity, and weaker basicity, respectively. La and 50Ce-50La catalysts displayed three CO2 desorption peaks. Physical adsorption is responsible for the low temperature desorption peak that was observed below 200°C, while chemical adsorption is responsible for the high temperature desorption peak that was observed above 400°C. Therefore, the removal of physical adsorption and weak chemical adsorption of CO2 molecules can be linked to the desorption peak that arises at the peak temperature of approximately 249°C for La and 194°C for 50Ce–50La [46]. Notably, the addition of La to Ce causes a peak shift towards a lower region with greater intensity, which suggests that the catalyst's defective sites have improved. Strong chemically adsorbed CO2 molecules are removed, which is responsible for the desorption peak that forms at the peak temperature of 400–600°C [46]. The synthesised materials pore structures were characterized using the N2 adsorption/desorption technique; Table 1 lists the sorption isotherms, pore size distributions, and textural characteristics. Type–IV N2 isotherms with an H2 hysteresis loop were seen in all samples (Fig. 6 b). Furthermore, the pore sizes were determined from the adsorption isotherms and the distribution of pore sizes in Fig. 6(c) and Table 1 indicated that they were mostly dispersed in the range of 2–3 nm [47]. The pore size and volume were reduced upon the introduction of La, probably as a result of the Ce–O–La network development. Table 1 shows that the BET surface areas of the 50Ce–50La samples were somewhat lower than those of the pure Ce samples (72 m2.g–1). Using ICP equipment, the percentage of Ce content was determined, is shown in Table 1. 3.1 Catalytic activity Ce, La and 50Ce–50La catalysts were tested in order to study the catalytic activity for the production of propylene carbonate (PC) from the reaction of propylene oxide (PO) and carbon dioxide (CO2) (Fig. 7 ) using a high pressure stainless steel autoclave reactor. Fig. 7(a) shows the PC yield and rate of PC formation (r PC) for the different catalysts. Pure Ce and La catalysts exhibits PC yield and r PC are 30 %, 47 % and 0.06 mol g–1, 0.094 molg–1, respectively. Interestingly, after the incorporation of La into Ce (50Ce–50La catalyst) those values are greatly increased; it is exhibited as PC yield (86.31%) and r PC (0.172 mol g–1). This yield is 2.8 and 1.8 times higher (PC) than the bare Ce and La samples, respectively. The reason for 50Ce–50La catalyst to perform better than other oxide catalysts could be due to its lowest particle size and increased Ce3+ that could have helped reactant molecules (PO and CO2) to access the available active catalytic sites with ease. Similarly, the rate of the reaction is also more favorable for 50Ce–50La mixed catalysts than bare Ce and La. The reaction temperature exhibited a significant impact on the catalytic processes. Fig. 7(b) shows the results of our investigation into the impact of reaction temperature on the production of PC from the reaction of PO and CO2 using 50Ce–50La at 20 bar constant pressure and 0.5 mg of catalyst amount. The 50Ce–50La catalyst showed a S PC of 98% and a 43% X PO at 100°C reaction temperature. The X PO increased from 43 to 87% as the reaction temperature reached 100 to 160°C, with a slightly increased S PC 99%. When further increased to a higher reaction temperature of 160°C to 180°C, the X PO rises to 89 %, while the S PC falls to 85 %. Similarly, the r PC gradually increases while the temperature increases to 160°C. When further increasing the temperature at 180°C the r PC decreases. This suggests that higher reaction temperatures favor a reduction in the production of PC. These results imply that the optimal temperature for achieving the high yield of PC is 160°C. Additionally, using the Arrhenius equation at the lower X PO level, the activation energies of the 50Ce–50La catalyst for the PO to PC reaction have been determined (Fig. 7 c). The exhibited activation energy of 50Ce–50La catalyst is 98.72 kJ mol–1. This is comparably smaller than other reported values [48,49,50,51]. Moreover, Turnover frequency values (TOFs) were calculated and displayed in Fig.S2. TOF is found to be the highest for the 50Ce-50La sample. Further, the catalytic activity of various La-loaded Ce catalysts was studied to determine how the La loading affects the catalyst's performance, and the results are shown in Fig.S3. Interestingly, while La loading is increased by 25 to 50 wt, % the catalytic activity gradually increases and further it is decline when goes to higher loading such as 75La-25Ce. This is further supported by P-XRD and XPS results. Among all the samples, the 50La-50Ce sample has the lowest crystalline size in P-XRD analysis. In addition, XPS results show when compared to bare Ce, the 50 wt.% La incorporated Ce shows enhanced reducibility oxygen vacancies. Fig. 7 (d) shows results from a study on the impact of reaction pressure on the 50Ce–50La catalyst. At a lower reaction pressure of 10 bars, the catalyst demonstrated 58% X PO and 95% S PO. Further raising the reaction pressure up to 20 bars resulted in gradual significant increases in X PO. At 20 bar pressure, maximum XPO (87%) and SPC (99%) were achieved. According to previous studies [49,48], reaction pressure has a major impact on the activation of PO on surfaces because it increases the probability that reactants will be present. Further increases in reaction pressure for 25 bars led to a decrease X PO as well as S PC. According to these findings, a 2 MPa reaction pressure is ideal for achieving the highest X PO and highest S PC. Also, one can notice that the Fig. 7(d) 2 MPa reaction pressure gives the highest r PC. The influence of 50Ce–50La catalyst on the PO to PC reaction has been investigated to determine the optimal reaction parameters, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 (a) (at 160°C and 20 bar pressure). We found as the catalyst amount increased, the S PC and X PO increased gradually and reached maximum activity at 0.5 g for the Ce–La catalyst. When further increases, the catalyst amount to 0.6 g noticed slightly decreases in S PC and X PO. Finally, the reaction and catalyst parameters are optimised; thus, all experiments were carried out with an optimal catalyst amount of 0.5 g, a temperature of 160°C, and 20 bar pressure. The catalyst reusability experiments were carried out to investigate the stability of the best-performing heterogeneous catalyst, i.e., 50Ce–50La. Fig. 8(b) shows the results of catalyst stability experiments conducted in a high-pressure stainless steel autoclave reactor with a fresh 50Ce–50La catalyst at a temperature of 160°C, 20 bar of pressure, and the ideal catalyst quantity of 0.5 g. Following the first run, the catalyst was filtered out of the reaction mixture, cleaned with acetone, and then centrifuged to recover it. After being dried for 12 hours at 80°C in an oven, the catalyst was utilized again for run 2. Subsequent runs were conducted using the same protocol. It is clear from Fig. 8(b) that there was no discernible drop in the yield and SPC, nor in the XPO after multiple runs. Overall, the 50Ce–50La catalyst demonstrates remarkable stability and reusability in the synthesis of PC, and it can be utilized multiple times without experiencing a notable reduction in its catalytic activity. There have been significant reports on PO to PC conversion in batch reactors using metal oxide-based heterogenous catalysts under various operating conditions and the results are summarized in Table.2 . According to the results, the reported catalysts had higher activity under high pressures. Among all the catalysts reported, Nb2O5 showed the highest yield 88%, at 50 bar pressure and 150°C for 12 h reaction time. 50Ce50La exhibits better catalytic activity than other catalysts (yield 69%) at mild operating conditions such as 130°C reaction temperature and 20 bar pressure within 6 h reaction time. The possible reaction pathway for the conversion of PO into PC over 50Ce-50La catalyst is displayed in Fig. 9 . The carboxylation process of propylene oxide is enhanced by the presence of a catalyst that possesses both acidic and basic sites. Carbon dioxide is adsorbed onto the basic sites offered by La2O3, whereas propylene oxide interacts with the acidic sites available from CeO2. The interaction occurs either between the carbon atom of the CO2 molecule and the oxygen anion of the metal oxide. Electrostatic interaction between metal oxide oxygen anion and CO2 molecule forms CO3 2− species on catalyst sites. Activated CO2 in carbonate forms breaks the epoxide ring structure, forming cyclic carbonate. Cyclic carbonate is desorbed, leaving vacant catalytic sites for further adsorption. 4 Conclusion Binary mixed metal oxides were studied as catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to yield cyclic carbonates. The addition of Ce is beneficial to the increase of the number of weak base sites on the catalyst surface and decreases the number of medium–strength base sites, which improves propylene oxide adsorption. HR-TEM results reveal that the shape of the particles is spherical in nature and exhibits an average particle size of 5 nm. Multiple oxidation states for cerium (Ce) and the simultaneous presence of oxygen vacancies were detected through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The Raman measurements provided additional insights. The shifting of the F2 g band and the absence of a peak corresponding to La suggest the incorporation of Ce3+ ions and the formation of Ce–La compounds. These observations were well–correlated with the catalytic performance. Thus, it is shown that these mixed oxides are efficient catalysts with good recyclability. It gives an excellent conversion of propylene oxide (87% of conversion and 99% selectivity) as well as good stability for up to 5 cycles under solvent-free conditions. coredata.dc:description: One of the most promising strategies for removing excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is CO2 utilization. Here, we describe the effective synthesis of propylene carbonate utilizing CeO2–La2O3 (Ce–La) mixed oxide, combining propylene oxide with carbon dioxide. The addition of La2O3 (La) to CeO2(Ce) resulted in an increase in oxygen vacancy, reducibility, and support–support interaction. Modifying the La:Ce ratio leads to a fine–tuning of the reducibility of the oxide, which can be explained by the formation of oxygen vacancies in the ceria lattice upon La addition. This modification also permits tailoring of the oxide morphology (lattice parameter, pore structure, particle size, and surface area). Powder X–ray diffraction (P–XRD), temperature programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2–TPR), Raman spectroscopy, BET surface area, and X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used to analyze the physico–chemical properties of the developed materials. Additionally, it demonstrates excellent catalytic activity for the solvent–free cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide, yielding 86%, and it maintains its high stability over five cycles without changing its shape.
